data.title: Fix initial collision pairs being cleared (2.1)
data.body:
This was affecting both 2D & 3D physics and was a regression introduced by my physics mega-fix (#8999).

Fixes #9387.

By the way, apologies for the bug and thank you for the patience as this was delaying the new release.

data.title: Ability to right-click resource box in the Inspector to access its menu
data.body:
Version: Godot 3.0 (master)

![screenshot from 2017-07-06 02-40-35](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/27100585/27875256-e1eead8c-61f5-11e7-930a-3e2c956422ff.png)

Right now that menu is only accessible by clicking on the little arrow, but I think adding the ability to just right-click the entire box would help a little with productivity. I'm not necessarily saying the arrow should be removed, but having a sort of context menu appear upon being right-clicked would be fairly intuitive to most.

data.title: Allow Godot 3.0 UI to be used as theme for game projects
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Windows 7 64-bit - Godot 3.0

**Issue description:**
Currently, when creating a game project with Godot 3.0, the old Godot theme is used for any UI components within your project. It would be great if there was an option to use the new Godot 3.0 theme for your project. This would especially benefit application-type projects or games that are more UI-oriented.

data.title: Filling values inside VS switch block is broken
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Linux, 00afca31c65812ecc5dfe6c4c92627c476ea8ea5

**Issue description:**
After adding switch block it's impossible to fill case values. 
Strangely after:
```
1. Connecting input String value
2. Removing String connection 
```
it suddenly started to works as expected:
![vs_switch_case_input](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6129594/27869784-489b31fe-61a1-11e7-99ef-76f69b20d32a.gif)

But immediately after connecting the String input it's not working again:
![vs_switch_case_input2](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6129594/27870060-257911ae-61a2-11e7-8908-a5512eb47977.gif)

Also please note that I haven't found any way to fill value for `int` (and other types) inputs

**Steps to reproduce:**
Add any Switch VS Block and try to fill it's inputs for comparison.

**Link to minimal example project:**
<!-- Optional but very welcome. You can drag and drop a zip archive to upload it. -->

data.title: Fix typo in plist export for OSX export
data.body: Noticed this while doing the iPhone export, it exports the zero terminator and for some reason skipped the first 9 characters... Unless there was a good reason for this I'm guessing it shouldn't be doing this :)

data.title: iPhone exporter for Godot 3.0
data.body:
This is still a work in progress but the basics are there. @reduz as discussed on IRC, let me know what needs changing to get it to export textures in the correct format etc.

In order to use this you need the following template file:
https://www.dropbox.com/s/wovvh0wxavowyk9/iphone.zip?dl=0
This is just a sample file for now, it doesn't have the correct binaries in it, they are both 64bit only debug builds of todays master. What is important are the project files. Important for that person who will make a final version, the files are stripped of any user files, xcode will create those, make sure you strip them out of your copy too.

Note that I am using XCode 9 beta at the moment but I think the template will work from XCode 7 and up.

The exporter will ask the user for an xcodeproj file to export too. 
The name you use will be used for the other folders and files as well to brand the project.
The folder in which this file is to be created will be used to extract the contents of the zip file in. Both the project files and plist files will be parsed for placeholders. 

After the export is done xcode is started and the project file is loaded (this last step works only on Mac OS X and only if xcode is configured to be the default app to open xcodeproj files with)

Things left todo (possibly not as part of this PR):
- export data pack with correct textures
- investigate creating correct attributes file for App Store sandboxing (or leave this up to xcode?)
- check completeness and requirements set in plist file
- deal with icons

data.title: Add a 'child_offset' attribute in the control node.
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
3.0

Hi,
While going through the code of GraphEdit, I figured out that it did use a special offset value to place each node (the `offset` attribute within GraphNode). Consequently, this forces EditorGraph to handle GraphNodes, but no other kind of control. This is, in my humble opinion, quite a limitation. Any kind of control should be displayable on such a scrolling area.

Thus, I was wondering why not use the position value instead, but the fact is that it is used to draw each control relatively to its parent. And as its position may be a fixed value (the GraphEdit does not move), it is not easy to move of child nodes.

To simplify all of this, I wanted to suggest a new `child_offset` attribute in a control node, this would display all child nodes with the given offset. This would also enable a scrollable area with arbitrarily placed nodes (without the container, which automatically resizes the child nodes).

What do you think ?

data.title: Slow access to getters, setters and node properties
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Windows 10 Pro 64 - Godot 2.1.3-stable

**Issue description:**

Analyzing the bunnymark code once again, we found that the use of getters, setters and accessing nodes properties turn the execution of the code much slower.

this is the original bunny.gd code ([full project here](https://github.com/Shin-NiL/Godot-BunnyMark-CPP/tree/master/projects/godot-bunnymark-gdscript)):
```
extends Sprite

var velocity = Vector2(0, 0)
var gravity = 3
var max_x = 640
var min_x = 0
var max_y = 480
var min_y = 0


func _ready():
	var tex = preload("res://wabbit_alpha.png")
	set_texture(tex)
	velocity.x = randf() * 10
	velocity.y = rand_range(5, 10)
	set_process(true)
	
func _process(delta):
	var pos = get_pos()

	pos.x += velocity.x
	pos.y += velocity.y
	velocity.y += gravity
		
	if (pos.x > max_x):
		velocity.x *= -1
		pos.x = max_x
	elif (pos.x < min_x):
		velocity.x *= -1
		pos.x = min_x
		
	if (pos.y > max_y):
		velocity.y *= -0.8
		pos.y = max_y
		if (randf() > 0.5):
			velocity.y -= randf() * 12;
		 
	elif (pos.y < min_y):
		velocity.y = 0;
		pos.y = min_y;
		
set_pos(pos)
```

Exporting the executable to release mode we get:
Bunnies: 7000
FPS: ~49

Changing it to avoid using Vector2 properties:

```
extends Sprite
var velocity_x = 0
var velocity_y = 0
var gravity = 3
var max_x = 640
var min_x = 0
var max_y = 480
var min_y = 0

func _ready():
    var tex = preload("res://wabbit_alpha.png")
    set_texture(tex)
    velocity_x= randf() * 10
    velocity_y = rand_range(5, 10)
    set_process(true)
    
func _process(delta):
    var pos = get_pos()
    var pos_x = pos.x
    var pos_y = pos.y
    pos_x += velocity_x
    pos_y += velocity_y
    velocity_y += gravity
    if (pos_x > max_x):
        velocity_x*= -1
        pos_x = max_x
    elif (pos_x < min_x):
        velocity_x*= -1
        pos_x = min_x
    if (pos_y > max_y):
        velocity_y *= -0.8
        pos_y = max_y
        if (randf() > 0.5):
            velocity_y -= randf() * 12;
    elif (pos_y < min_y):
        velocity_y = 0;
        pos_y = min_y;
    set_pos(Vector2(pos_x, pos_y))
```

Exporting the executable to release mode we get:
Bunnies: 8000
FPS: ~54
(If we were able to get rid of get_pos and set_pos the results would be even better)

My question is: is that behavior expected? The user \_807\_ from godotdevelopers forum even adapted the code to use the shower of bullets approach with no notable gain of performance. [Here's the full discussion thread.](https://godotdevelopers.org/forum/discussion/18435/bunny-mark-performance)

data.title: Added missing binding to _owner_exited
data.body: Fixes #9503

data.title: Add secondary alignment to BoxContainer
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**

The parameter `alignment` of BoxContainer works perfectly in the GUI layout.  But we still hard to control the *secondary* alignment of child nodes in BoxContainers. Like the picture shows

![BoxContainer for now](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6964556/27854197-60f38700-6198-11e7-8406-4b5b8043aa0c.png)

Neither the horizental alignment of nodes in VBoxContaoner nor the vertical alignment of nodes in HBoxContainer could be changed. The secondary alignment is always be `center`.

So I hope we can have another parameter to control this layout behavior like `align-items` in flexbox

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6964556/27854502-959b5be4-6199-11e7-83d9-d40e938fdeb1.png)

data.title: ParticleAttractor2D causes errors when exiting tree
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Godot 2.1.3-stable


**Issue description:**
When a ParticleAttractor2D and its Particle2D exits the tree no 'exit_tree' signal exists and it fails calling ParticleAttractor2D::_owner_exited

```
ERROR: emit_signal: Error calling method from signal 'exit_tree': 'ParticleAttractor2D::_owner_exited': Method not found.
   At: core/object.cpp:1162.

ERROR: disconnect: Nonexistent signal: exit_tree
   At: core/object.cpp:1415.
```


**Steps to reproduce:**
1. Create a new scene
2. Add a Particle2D and a ParticleAttractor2D
3. Assign the Particle2D to the 'Particle Path' on the ParticleAttractor2D
4. Save and exit the scene

data.title: Simple calculations in inspector integer/float inputs

It will be nice if inspector could understand simple calculations like 64 + 64 + 10 resulting into 138 but not 64. It will help to place GUI and other game elements faster (if you need to set it by hand in scene).
i am at version 3.0 alpha

data.title: Dictionary.parse_json() turns integers into floats.
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Godot 2.1.2 - Ubuntu 17.10 

**Issue description:**
Hi everyone !
When I turn a JSON file into a GDScript dictionary, every integer values are turned into floats.
Are you able to reproduce it with the following example ?

**Steps to reproduce:**
Here is an JSON file example:
```
{
    "height": 4,
    "width": 4,
}
```

And here is the way I parse its content into a dictionary:

```gdscript
    var file = File.new()
    file.open("my_file.json", file.READ)
    
    var tmp_text = file.get_as_text()
    file.close()

    var tmp_dict = {}
    tmp_dict.parse_json(tmp_text)

    var height = tmp_dict['height']
    var width = tmp_dict['width']

    print(typeof(height))
    # 3
    print(typeof(width))
    # 3
```

data.title: Use the gravity constant to calculate weights
data.body:
Fixes #9150.
The issue was indeed also present in 3D.
Notice how in 2D the constant is multiplied by 10 and is an integer whereas in 3D it  isn't scaled and is a float. It seems a bit weird to me but I left it as is.

data.title: 5.1 and 7.1 surround sound not working
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Windows 10 - Godot 2 & 3

**Issue description:**
Trying to play spatial sound only works as left and right sound (stereo) ignoring the surround setup. It seems that in the code it's hardcoded to STEREO and the needed code is commented or has FIXME comments

Also there's no info on how to use surround sound, so maybe it's just not being set up correctly. I changed the audio Project Settings to 'surround' instead of 'stereo' with no luck

data.title: Atlas textures don't work with Sprite3Ds
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
2.1.4-beta, at least on Linux

**Issue description:**
When setting a Sprite3D's texture property to an *.atex file, it isn't displayed properly. Sometimes you can see other parts of the texture atlas than your *.atex file represents.

data.title: fix for redundant RMB options for toplevel node
data.body:
https://github.com/godotengine/godot/pull/9484 introduced a bug in RMB menu. 
There were redundant options for [not inherited] scene root node. In that case options for instanced node were presented. 
Now I'm recognizing if node is the most toplevel one in current context with, with `get_owner()==NULL`.

data.title: NormalizedOffset parameter for sprite
data.body:
Now there is only *Offset* for sprite, it is a little complex to put anchor at a sprite's feet since I need to check the height of the image to type the Y value.

How about a *NormalizedOffset* parameter? It is in range 0-1, and (when *Centered* checked)  I just need to set it (0, 0.5) to move the anchor to the sprite's feet.
